9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:46): hi :> !! Is it more correct to use a link with href="javascript:function()" or any other element like <li> or <p> with event onclick="function()" ?

233ca1f467e8dabcd3aa31cbb31694d9 (02:47): xlogic: Neither is more correct.  onclick is preferred on elements where href can be used to specify a page to load if Javascript is disabled, and javascript: obviously won't work on anything other than a link.
b18619a4351cb0e11e37b0d5d5760826 (02:48): What's the license on prototype?
8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (02:48): xlogic: href="javascript:" should be avoided. The choice between a link and another elements depends on context.
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:49): the contenxt is that javascript is mandatory to be activated and supported in the app i'm making
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:49): if js is disabled by the browser ...it just doesn't make any sense
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:50): i'm working with ajax
b18619a4351cb0e11e37b0d5d5760826 (02:50): Then use client-side DOM listeners in the first place.
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:51): add the event with dom ??
b18619a4351cb0e11e37b0d5d5760826 (02:51): Yes.  You add an event listener programmatically when the page loads.  Much cleaner.
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:52): ok ... but then i should connect the event onclick to some element like <p> or <li>
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:52): is that the most standard way ?
b18619a4351cb0e11e37b0d5d5760826 (02:53): No, you still attach it to a clickable element, like a.

bc075c41a4d2dbb1abbdf399c9738994 (02:53): I have an Ajax script that fades (scriptaculous effect.fade) the content of a div out before displaying the content of the active div. The content is a rather long list so when the old content fades out, the new content jumps to the top of the screen out of view (window is scrolled). Is there a way to make the browser show the appropriate div? Each div in the list has its own unique id.
bc075c41a4d2dbb1abbdf399c9738994 (02:54): I'm thinking of something similar to an anchor tag, but without having to click
9120874bdd7b85ba45d69d7728790069 (02:54): ah ok Crell42 ... but use the onclick event of the anchor and not the href property
b18619a4351cb0e11e37b0d5d5760826 (02:54): xlogic: http://www.sitepoint.com/books/dhtml1/ - read the first few sample chapters. Quick read, but really lays out fully-client-side hookup well.
c95720c193df40ce1618d1b00b040b42 (02:54): js links: http://www.alistapart.com/articles/popuplinks/ , http://tom.me.uk/scripting/links.asp
6735c9ab9b1ac69d7d2f449177128eca (02:55): never use an anchor for a js event
6735c9ab9b1ac69d7d2f449177128eca (02:55): unless you have a backup behaviour in the href of course
